comments.text: A lot of cars, almost all go to Tashkent. Just gotta find the one that agrees to take you for free. Didn't take me too long though. A lot of taxi drivers at the border trying to take you but just ignore them and walk here.
BTW. Note some people selling some goods near crossroads. They are the last chance to exchange somonis to sums and vise versa.
Here is police check point located. They ot a roof where you can hide from the sun. Lots of cars to Tashkent.
Sign for Tashkent had me picked up in minutes.  Make sure you tell them you're not paying.
Walk passed the taxis and there's a decent place for drivers to pull in.  Almost everyone will want money, but stick to your guns and you'll get a free ride eventually.
Got picked up by a taxi for a free ride to the edge of the city.  Winning.
Just walking along this road and you'll get a ride without even trying.  As ever just make sure it's for free.
Fend off the offers for a taxi.  You'll get a ride eventually.
Just over the border on the Uzbekistan side.  Walk along this road with a sign and/or your thumb out and you'll get picked up sooner or later.  Plenty of trucks going in both directions.

here is roadpolice checkpoint located. ask policemans to get a ride for you (usually bus) or try your own
p.s. you can reach this place by taxistop. uzbek taxists able to transport you for free after short explanation about your h-hiking soul. :)
waiting time less than 30 mins

siberian_explorer
Totaly agree with previous comment. Same story. Me and my girlfriend wait just 1 minute. Many trucks go to Russia/Kazahstan
Direct ride to Urgench. Make sure your ride is free. Took a Yandex to get here. Costs only like a euro.
Truck to Bukhara pretty much instantly after my previous ride.

A lot of traffic, most of it to Tashkent. Many taxi drivers after the border but just ignore them. In less than a minute a friendly local and his son stopped for us and took us all the way to the capital. Easy hitchhiking spot
Truckdriver took me and my brother to Bukhara. Make sure it is free beforehand.
Perfect spot for the Tajik border. Just say "Granitsa" and make sure it's for free like always in this region.
Literally got out of my previous car and the car behind us told me to hop in. Other than that, the spot itself seemed great too, plenty of cars and room.
Took a taxi to here from the town center for like 2€ and got a free ride to Moynaq very quickly.
Here is a cafe where truck drivers stop to take a rest. We got a direct ride to Kazakhstan border from here. The road is in a bad condition, so it took as 6+ hours to get there.
Used a Samarqand sign, got a ride 30km along the road.
Sign for Samarkand (in Russian) got me picked up in minutes.
Anywhere along this road will do.  Lots of space to pull in.  Ensure the ride is for free.
There is a few buses to Yangibozor. Bus turns left, you follow the road.
Free ride to Urgut.
Direction Sharisabz. Most probably you wil pay for the ride.
5 mins and a guy took me for free because he wanted to talk.
Malik Raboti caravanserai

Simple spot by the road side at the "edge" of town walkable from the city center. To get further out take a mashrutka (1500 Som, from close to the bus station) to Ambop - a town roughly 10 km down the road north, walk a bit and start hitching. Sufficient local traffic to Sherabad.
Police check point. Good place to catch long rides (Bukhara / Samarkand). Between Termiz and Sherabad there's quite some local traffic. However, from Sherabad onwards traffic gets thin until Gusar.

it's easy to get here from metro.  lots of taxi cars passing by this place on their way to border. talk with taxi drivers and you will get taxi ride for free right till border control.
waiting time tended to zero

siberian_explorer

Use Yandex until this spot (cca. 1.5 €)
It is not bad spot, we wait a bit
Just walk away from the taxis and you'll find a free ride. I was lucky and asked an american tour bus full of elderly if they had space for me and they did :D
I was hitchiking to Bukhara, got a ride for Navoy. There is a little space on the side where cars can stop.
Ride to Samarkand, at the end the driver asked for money, always talk money beforehand
Great spot in the shade. Used a Samarqand sign and found a free ride (although they thought I had lost all my money or something)
It seems like a bad spot but it's surprisingly not. Has a lot of cars and they all seem to go to the highway. I found one to Nukus after 15 mins.
Just stand anywhere after the town and you'll find a ride out in no time. There's some shared taxis going up and down Moynaq so you can reach here with those or with a normal taxi.

Don't take any of the taxis after the border but just walk until there's no people and start hh. Not too many cars but some trucks. Road is horrible but they're building a new one currently. Took me 9 hours to reach Kungrad by truck. Should be a bit faster in a car. Bring some snacks and water.

Border was easy on foot. They usually let you skip the lines if they see you're a foreigner. Took me an hour all in all.
Nice spot to get to south uzbekistan, towards G'uzor and Termiz, lots of cars passing by
Here is the main exit form Kokand to Khudjand in Tajikistan. Either try dozens of local cars or use bus to Besharyk and further (price from Kokand to border is 0,5 usd)

You can stuck here if your car from Tashkent goes to Namangan but you want to go further. There is one important detail about this place - there is a crossroad not far from there and drivers will show you their direction either to the right if he goes to Kokand or left if he goes to Fergana via circular road around Kokand. This gestures a bit misleading so it took a while to figure out this issue.
There are many buses to Hippodrome market (Ипподром). Cross roundabout, then cross police checkpoint and right after it start hitching. There is a way to cheat a bit - ask police to help you.
Any local car towards Denov is okay. I tried Uzun and it was more or less fast.

After crossing into Uzbekistan ignore the armada of taxi drivers and walk a bit further on out of their sight. There's basically no through traffic here except some few trucks coming from Tajikistan (around two trucks/hour).
Nice option for those who want to cross spectacular Kaynar pass.
Spot on the road side at the edge of town. Not many villages between here and Samarkand - so mostly shared taxis.
Not to many cars towards the Tajik border.
Seemed like a good spot to head to Bukhara but it's just small village after village and nobody driving far distances. Take the route through Urgench!
